import seaborn as sns

%matplotlib inline
source.d0fbef28:
# write a function for data clearning which includes renaming of columns by replacing space with _ and handling non numeric values
# from numeric columns
def clean_auto_data(auto_df):
    'Function to load the auto price data set from a .csv file' 
    ## Rename Coulmns so the '-' character becomes '_'
    cols = auto_df.columns
    auto_df.columns = [str.replace('-', '_') for str in cols]
    
    ## Treat missing values remove rows with missing values, accounting for mising values coded as '?'
    num_cols = ['price', 'bore', 'stroke','horsepower', 'peak_rpm']
    for column in num_cols:
        auto_df.loc[auto_df[column] == '?', column] = np.nan
    auto_df.dropna(axis = 0, inplace = True)

    ## Transform column data type, Convert columns to numeric values
    for column in num_cols:
        auto_df[column] = pd.to_numeric(auto_df[column])
    
    return auto_df

# perform data cleaning on auto data frame
auto_df = clean_auto_data(auto_df)

print(auto_df.columns)

def count_unique(auto_prices, cols):
    for col in cols:
        print('\n' + 'For column ' + col)
        print(auto_prices[col].value_counts())

cat_cols = ['make', 'fuel_type', 'aspiration', 'num_of_doors', 'body_style', 
            'drive_wheels', 'engine_location', 'engine_type', 'num_of_cylinders', 
            'fuel_system']
count_unique(auto_df, cat_cols)
source.ff178c16:
def barplot_method (auto_df, cols):
    for col in cols:
        fig = plt.figure(figsize=(12,6)) # define plot area
        ax = fig.gca() # define axis    
        counts = auto_df[col].value_counts() # find the counts for each unique category
        counts.plot.bar(ax = ax, color = 'blue') # Use the plot.bar method on the counts data frame
        ax.set_title('Number of autos by' + col) # Give the plot a main title
        ax.set_xlabel(col) # Set text for the x axis
        ax.set_ylabel('Number of autos')# Set text for y axis
        plt.show()

cat_cols = ['make', 'fuel_type', 'aspiration', 'num_of_doors', 'body_style', 'drive_wheels', 'engine_location', 'engine_type',
            'num_of_cylinders', 'fuel_system']
barplot_method(auto_df, cat_cols)
source.3e45f99b:
def plot_histogram(auto_prices, cols, bins = 10):
    for col in cols:
        fig = plt.figure(figsize=(12,6)) # define plot area
        ax = fig.gca() # define axis    
        auto_prices[col].plot.hist(ax = ax, bins = bins) # Use the plot.hist method on subset of the data frame
        ax.set_title('Histogram of ' + col) # Give the plot a main title
        ax.set_xlabel(col) # Set text for the x axis
        ax.set_ylabel('Number of autos')# Set text for y axis
        plt.show()
        
num_cols = ['curb_weight', 'engine_size', 'city_mpg', 'price']    
plot_histogram(auto_df, num_cols)
source.a4dcc63b:
def plot_density_hist(auto_prices, cols, bins = 10, hist = False):
    for col in cols:
        fig = plt.figure(figsize=(12,6)) # define plot area
        ax = fig.gca() # define axis           
        sns.set_style("whitegrid")
        sns.distplot(auto_prices[col], bins = bins, rug=True, hist = hist)
        plt.title('Histogram of ' + col) # Give the plot a main title
        plt.xlabel(col) # Set text for the x axis
        plt.ylabel('Number of autos')# Set text for y axis
        plt.show()
        
plot_density_hist(auto_df, num_cols)
source.66d67720:
def plot_scatter(auto_prices, cols, col_y = 'price'):
    for col in cols:
        fig = plt.figure(figsize=(12,6)) # define plot area
        ax = fig.gca() # define axis   
        auto_prices.plot.scatter(x = col, y = col_y, ax = ax)
        ax.set_title('Scatter plot of ' + col_y + ' vs. ' + col) # Give the plot a main title
        ax.set_xlabel(col) # Set text for the x axis
        ax.set_ylabel(col_y
                     )# Set text for y axis
        plt.show()

num_cols = ['curb_weight', 'engine_size', 'horsepower', 'city_mpg']
plot_scatter(auto_df, num_cols)
source.517f186e:
def plot_desity_2d(auto_prices, cols, col_y = 'price', kind ='kde'):
    for col in cols:
        sns.set_style("whitegrid")
        sns.jointplot(col, col_y, data=auto_prices, kind=kind)
        plt.xlabel(col) # Set text for the x axis
        plt.ylabel(col_y)# Set text for y axis
        plt.show()

plot_desity_2d(auto_df, num_cols)
source.0c91ec4b:
def plot_box(auto_prices, cols, col_y = 'price'):
    for col in cols:
        sns.set_style("whitegrid")
        sns.boxplot(col, col_y, data=auto_prices)
        plt.xlabel(col) # Set text for the x axis
        plt.ylabel(col_y)# Set text for y axis
        plt.show()
        
cat_cols = ['fuel_type', 'aspiration', 'num_of_doors', 'body_style', 
            'drive_wheels', 'engine_location', 'engine_type', 'num_of_cylinders']
plot_box(auto_df, cat_cols)
source.b8ac5eea:
def plot_violin(auto_prices, cols, col_y = 'price'):
    for col in cols:
        sns.set_style("whitegrid")
        sns.violinplot(col, col_y, data=auto_prices)
        plt.xlabel(col) # Set text for the x axis
        plt.ylabel(col_y)# Set text for y axis
        plt.show()
        
plot_violin(auto_df, cat_cols)
source.be248158:
def plot_violin_hue(auto_prices, cols, col_y = 'price', hue_col = 'aspiration'):
    for col in cols:
        sns.set_style("whitegrid")
        sns.violinplot(col, col_y, data=auto_prices, hue = hue_col, split = True)
        plt.xlabel(col) # Set text for the x axis
        plt.ylabel(col_y)# Set text for y axis
        plt.show()
        
plot_violin_hue(auto_df, cat_cols)
source.d049e908:
What is bin 
if there is a columns which has range of 1 to 10000 and if want to see frequency distribution of data on 5 bins. It will create  bins as follows:

1) 1 to 2000 
2) 2001 to 4000
3) 4001 to 6000
4) 6001 to 8000
5) 8001 to 10000

and then it will present count of records i.e. frequency distribution over aforementioned bins of data.

source.08ebdbe6:
I am preparing a series to understand data visualization into super simple way by decomposing complex aspects of of data visualization in to small units and make it super easy to understand. We can decompose Data Visualization in following parts:

Data Visualization for individual columns (Numerical and Categorical both)

Data Visualization to explore relationship between two numerical columns

Data Visualization to explore relationship between numerical and categorical columns

I have created individual jupyter notebook for all aforementioned 3 parts and in this notebook I am compiling these concepts
source.a309c855: We can use aesthetics like color coding to add project additional dimensions to plot. Example aforemention violin plot analyze relationship between two columns we can use color or hue to include third column and analyze relationship between three column at the same time. E.g. We can use split violin plots where violins are split by type of auto_df['aspiration'] column and shown in different colors.
source.fd5e492b: # Visualize the frequency of Categorical variables using bar chart
source.d9a3634f: Another way to explore frequency distribution of numerical columns over the bins is using kernel density plot of Seaborn library. We can think of Kernel Density plots as smoothed version of Histograms
source.a3e38797:
In Frequency distribution we analyze how many time a particular value of a columns appeared in a given table forexample for car make columns we want to see how many times Toyota appeared in the dataframe, how many times Nissan appeared in dataframe etc.

We use value_count() method or bar plots to analyze frequency distribution of categorical columns and we use histogram or kernel density plots to analyze frequeny distribution of numerical columns
source.a74481d9: # Analyzing one column at a time using frequency distribution analysis
source.5f408b74:
## Visualizing relationshops between the data of various columns

Some key tricks:
1. If we are analyzing relationships between two numerical columns we can use charts like scatter plots
2. We can analyze relationship between a categorical column and numerical column using box or violin plots where we can check the distribution of numerical values over various categories of a categorical columns. for example we can understand the relationship between car make columns which has values like 'Toyota', '', '' etc and price columns. we can create a box plot which can display price distribution for each of car make****
source.9d83230d:
Strong relationship between these numerical features and prices means, these features will be useful in predicting the price of autos.

We can use joint plot as well to explore relationship between various columns and can explore the frequncy distribution of individaul columns at the same time
